p.s: I hope you're doing good and well, but I think I need to talk to you about one specific topic.
Your statement earlier, that student exchanges are a waste of time gave me something to think about, and I am afraid I have to disagree with you.

I do understand your point of view, because for some people, it really is, for some it is even a very bad decision because they don't understand anything in school so their grades drop, but that is by far not everyone.
Many students who did exchanges are really happy now that they decided to do so, because it is a big opportunity.

At first, there is the language aspektaspect: As soon as you are living in another country, you need to adapt to the language thatsthat's spoken there, and if not, you need to use at least English, because it is the world language.
This will improve your language skills very fast, so at the end of it, many students speak fluently or nearly fluently a second/another language.
That is a huge pro because it is not as hard as learning it on your own or at school with other people around you who speak your native language.

Then there is also the cultural aspektaspect: You visit another country, so therefore, there are many diffrentdifferent holidays, diffrentdifferent ways how the people interact with each other and so on.
You really learn something about the culture, which helps you becoming more open minded and cosmopolitan.
If more people would do exchanges, it would probably be a huge help on issues like racism.

All in all iI would like to say that I am a big fan of student exchanges, even if I have never been on one, because to me it seems like such a huge adventure, which I would not want to miss out, and also would not want you to miss out because it can be a lot of fun.
I hope I could help you a little bit more on that topic because you seemed a little uninformed to me.
